metadata.title: Effects of ablation energy and post-irradiation on the structure and properties of titanium dioxide nanomaterials

ull Length Article
ffects of ablation energy and post-irradiation on the structure and roperties of titanium dioxide nanomaterials
. García Guilléna, S. Shaji a,b,∗, M. I. Mendivil Palmac, D. Avellanedaa, G.A. Castilloa, .K. Das Roya, D.I. García Gutiérreza,b, B. Krishnana,b
Universidad Autónoma de Nuevo León, Facultad de Ingeniería Mecánica y Eléctrica, San Nicolás de los Garza, Nuevo León 66455, México Universidad Autónoma de Nuevo León-CIIDIT, Apodaca, Nuevo León, México Centro de Investigación en Materiales Avanzados (CIMAV), Unidad Monterrey, PIIT, Apodaca, Nuevo León, México
r t i c l e i n f o
rticle history: eceived 25 August 2016 eceived in revised form 14 January 2017 ccepted 26 January 2017 vailable online 3 February 2017
eywords: ulsed laser ablation in liquid
a b s t r a c t
Nanomaterials of titanium oxide were prepared by pulsed laser ablation of a titanium metal target in distilled water. The ablation was performed at different laser energy (fluence) using a nanosecond pulsed Nd:YAG laser output of 1064 and 532 nm. A post-irradiation of titanium oxide nanocolloids obtained by ablation using 532 nm was carried out to explore its effects on the structure and properties. Analysis of morphology, crystalline phase, elemental composition, chemical state, optical and luminescent properties were performed using Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM), X-Ray Diffraction (XRD), X-Ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS), UV–-vis absorption spectroscopy and room temperature pho-
itanium dioxide anomaterials EM PS ptical and luminescence properties
toluminescence spectroscopy. It was found that titanium oxide nanomaterial morphologies and optical properties were determined by ablation wavelength and fluence. Further, nanocolloids prepared by 532 nm ablation showed a crystalline phase change by laser post-irradiation. The results showed that pulsed laser ablation in liquid as well as post-irradiation were effective in modifying the final structure and properties of titanium oxide nanocolloids.
© 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
. Introduction
Titanium dioxide (TiO2) is a wide band gap semiconductor that ommonly exists in rutile (bandgap 3.0 eV) and anatase (band ap 3.2 eV) phases. It has been extensively studied for photocatlytic, hydrophilic, chemical stability properties and for a variety f applications such as in dye-sensitized solar cells, water/air urifier, environmental photo-catalyst, optoelectronic devices and as-sensors [1–4]. Various chemical preparation methods to synhesize nanostructured titanium dioxide were reported, such as ol–gel [5,6], hydrothermal [7], micro-emulsion [8] and solvotheral method [9]. However, recent studies on pulsed laser ablation n liquid media (PLALM), an environmental friendly process for the abrication of nanomaterials, have demonstrated as a promising echnique for synthesis of chemically pure nanoparticles in soluion [10–12]. Several research groups reported the synthesis of
∗ Corresponding author at: Universidad Autónoma de Nuevo León, Facultad de ngeniería Mecánica y Eléctrica, San Nicolás de los Garza, Nuevo León, 66455, México. el.: +52 18114920380.
E-mail addresses: sshajis@yahoo.com, sadasivan.shaji@uanl.edu.mx (S. Shaji).
ttp://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.apsusc.2017.01.282 169-4332/© 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
crystalline titanium dioxide nanoparticles by different conditions applied in PLALM, such as the use of different liquid media, laser beam focusing conditions and changing the laser parameters (laser wavelength, energy and pulse duration). Nath et al. [13,14] synthesized titanium dioxide nanoparticles with different particle size distributions and phases by changing the focusing conditions of the pulsed laser. Spherical TiO2 nanoparticles were produced by pulsed laser ablation of a titanium target in various liquid environments such as water, ethanol, 2-propanol, n-hexane [15], and at different concentrations of sodium n-dodecyl sulfate (SDS) [16,17]. Preparation of titanium dioxide nanoparticles with different morphologies and crystalline phases via pulsed laser ablation of a titanium target in water was done by varying the laser fluence [18–20] or the pulse width [21,22]. Also, TiO2 raw particles dispersed in liquid media were irradiated by a nanosecond pulsed laser [23]. In the present work, we report synthesis of titanium dioxide nanoparticles with different morphology, size and optical properties by varying the laser ablation wavelength and fluence. Also, the effects of postirradiation on TiO2 nanocolloids obtained at different fluence of 532 nm ablation are included. Post-irradiation of the titanium oxide nanomaterials produced by PLALM resulted in morphological and structural changes that are reported for the first time.

sections.heading: 84 G.G. Guillén et al. / Applied Su
sections.text:
. Experimental
The ablation experiments were performed using the fundamenal ( = 1064 nm) and the second harmonic ( = 532 nm) of a high ower Q-switched Nd:YAG laser system (Model LQ929, Solar Laser ystems) operated at 10 Hz with a pulse width of 10 ns. A laser nergy meter (Model PM100D, Thorlabs Inc.) was used to monitor he output energy of the 1064 and 532 nm laser beams; they were 00 and 230 mJ per pulse, respectively.
.1. Pulsed laser ablation of titanium (Ti) metal
High purity titanium rod (99.99% in purity) was used as the taret for the laser ablation. The target was placed at the bottom of a lass vessel filled with 15 ml of distilled water. Laser output (532 r 1064 nm) was focused using a convex lens of focal length 20 cm. n the ablation setup, the distance between the lens and target was aried to obtain different ablation energy (fluence). For the 1064 nm utput ablation, the estimated fluence values were 4.7, 8.7, 20.4 and 5.9 J/cm2. For laser ablation using 532 nm, the estimated fluence ere 2.8, 6.0, 19.4 and 27.6 J/cm2 respectively. Ablation time was
min for all the experiments. After the ablation experiment, disilled water turned into a turbid solution due to the presence of anoparticles.
.2. Laser post-irradiation of titanium nanocolloids
The colloidal solutions obtained by pulsed laser ablation of titaium rod in distilled water by 532 nm at different laser fluence were ubjected to a laser post-irradiation using the unfocused 532 nm aser beam from the Nd:YAG laser. First, 15 ml of each colloidal olution was irradiated for 10 min and another set of colloids were rradiated for 20 min. The colloidal solutions were stirred continously during post-irradiation to avoid their agglomeration and recipitation. The laser fluence estimated for post-irradiation was .23 J/cm2. For the nanocolloids, 532 nm has better absorption than he fundamental (1064 nm). So 532 nm output was chosen for post rradiation. The absorption coefficient of the TiO2 nanocolloids at 32 nm was 0.22 cm−1. The nanocolloid used for post-irradiation 15 ml) was 1.2 cm thick.
.3. Material characterization
Drops of all the colloidal solutions prepared at different ablation onditions were dried separately on carbon-copper grids to charcterize their morphology, size and structure using Transmission lectron Microscopy (TEM, Model FEI Titan G2 80-300). Calibraion for the TEM is done using a standard Silicon sample. All the amples were dried on conducting copper tapes to perform Xay photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis (Thermo Scientific nc. Model K-Alpha). This analysis was done with a monochromtized Al K radiation (E = 1486.68 eV). A fraction of the colloidal olution was centrifuged and dried on a glass substrate to characerize its structure by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using a diffractometer mploying Cu K 1 radiation ( = 1.5406 Å, Bruker D8 Advance) at ormal mode. The scan range (2 ) was 10◦–70◦. The nanocolloids ere subjected to UV–vis absorption analysis using a UV–vis dual eam Spectrophotometer (Shimadzu UV-1800) in the wavelength ange of 300–1000 nm. The colloidal solution was taken in a quartz uvette with 1 cm path length and the reference liquid (distilled
ater) also. Photoluminescence (PL) spectra of all these nanocoloids were measured using a Fluorescence Spectrometer (LS 55 erkin Elmer). The results on morphology, structure, chemical comosition, optical and luminescence properties of these titanium
Science 405 (2017) 183–194
oxide nanomaterials obtained by pulsed laser ablation at different laser ablation conditions were analyzed.
3. Results and discussion
3.1. Morphology and structure by TEM analysis
TEM analysis was carried out to study the morphology, size and structure of the ablation products. Figs. 1–5 show the TEM images, size distribution of spherical nanoparticles as well as selected area electron diffraction (SAED) analysis of these titanium oxide nanomaterials obtained for different ablation conditions. Size of the nanoparticles was measured using Gatan Microscopy Suite software and the Digital Micrograph for Transmission Electron Microscopy image analysis. For each sample, five TEM images were selected and the diameters of the spherical nanoparticles only were measured using the LineROI tool for length measurement. Then, all nanoparticles diameter data were analyzed in OriginPro 8 software and their frequency counts were made by the statistics tool. The average size and standard deviation for nanoparticles were analyzed by descriptive statistics tool considering the size range of 1–40 nm. The presence of agglomerated tiny particles might have affected the average size evaluated. Average size and size distribution of these nanoparticles are evaluated from different TEM images collected from the same sample grid. Nanomaterials with different morphologies are obtained for the colloids prepared by laser ablation with 1064 nm for different fluence (Fig. 1). Spherical nanoparticles are obtained for the ablation of titanium rod at a fluence of 4.7 J/cm2 as observed in Fig. 1a. These nanoparticles are agglomerated and their selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern in Fig. 1b is indexed for TiO2 rutile crystalline phase (PDF No. 04-008-7645). Their size distribution histogram is included as inset in Fig. 1a, with an average size of 13 ± 7.2 nm. As the laser fluence is changed to 8.7 J/cm2, needle-shaped nanostructures with a few spherical nanoparticles are formed, as in Fig. 1c. The rings of electron diffraction points of the needle-shaped nanostructures (Fig. 1d) correspond to the crystalline planes of TiO2 anatase phase (PDF No. 04-007-0701). When the laser fluence of ablation is increased to 20.4 J/cm2, needle shaped nanostructures as well as spherical nanoparticles (Fig. 1e) are formed. The SAED rings of these nanostructures (Fig. 1f) are indexed and the interplanar distances measured are in agreement with the (101), (112), (200), (105), (116) and (204) diffraction planes of TiO2 anatase phase. The average size of those spherical nanoparticles observed in Fig. 1e (20.4 J/cm2) is 19 ± 7.3 nm. As the fluence is increased to 45.9 J/cm2, needle shaped nanostructures disappeared and only spherical nanoparticles are obtained (Fig. 1g). Those bigger spherical nanoparticles are surrounded by an agglomerated zone of tiny spherical particles as well as some ablated material. In this case, the average size of the spherical nanoparticles estimated is 12 ± 6.4 nm. The electron diffraction of these nanoparticles is indexed to anatase TiO2 phase as included in Fig. 1h.
The morphology of nanoparticles obtained by pulsed laser ablation using 532 nm laser wavelength consists of mainly spherical nanoparticles (Figs. 2–5). These nanocolloids were also postirradiated using 532 nm laser output at a fluence of 0.23 J/cm2 for 10 and 20 min. Fig. 2 shows the morphologies of nanoparticles obtained at fluence of 2.8 J/cm2 (Fig. 2a) and its post-irradiation of 10 min (Fig. 2c) and 20 min (Fig. 2e). Spherical nanoparticles with average size of 13 ± 6.1 nm are obtained for the ablation at 2.8 J/cm2 (Fig. 2a) and their SAED pattern indexed is in agreement with rutile TiO2 phase as shown in Fig. 2b. When these colloids were irradiated for 10 min with unfocused 532 nm laser beam, larger (average size of 17 ± 7.9 nm) agglomerated spherical nanoparticles are obtained (Fig. 2c). Well dispersed spherical nanoparticles with

a o s t e s f
verage size of 15 ± 5.8 nm are produced due to the post-irradiation f this nanocolloid for 20 min (Fig. 2e). The SAED patterns of these pherical nanoparticles (Fig. 2d and f, respectively) are indexed and he lattice parameters correspond to rutile phase. As the laser flunce is increased to 6.0 J/cm2, spherical nanoparticles with average ize of 13 ± 5.8 nm are formed (Fig. 3a). The SAED pattern (Fig. 3b) or these spherical nanoparticles are indexed to (110), (101), (111),
(210) and (211) planes of TiO2 rutile tetragonal crystalline phase. After their post-irradiation for 10 min (Fig. 3c), the average size of spherical nanoparticles is increased to 16 ± 5.7 nm. 20 min irradiation of the as prepared nanocolloid (6.0 J/cm2) turns to spherical nanoparticles with an average size of 14 ± 5.5 nm (Fig. 3e). The SAED patterns for both colloidal products (Fig. 3d and f) are in agreement with the lattice parameters of rutile crystalline phase. The laser

ig. 5. TEM images, corresponding size histogram (inset) and the respective SAED p nd its laser post-irradiation during (c and d) 10 min and (e and f) 20 min using 532
5 ± 6.3 nm (Fig. 4c) and 16 ± 7.2 nm (Fig. 4e) are obtained respecively. SAED patterns are indexed to anatase (Fig. 4d) and rutile
Fig. 4f) phase respectively. When the ablation fluence is increased o 27.6 J/cm2, spherical nanoparticles with average size of 12 ± 5 nm re obtained (Fig. 5a). These nanoparticles are indexed to anorhic Ti8O15 crystalline phase as described in Fig. 5b. When these olloids are irradiated with the 532 nm laser for 10 min, needle haped nanomaterials linked to each other and spherical nanoparicles with average size of 14 ± 5.7 nm are obtained as in Fig. 5c. he electron diffraction spots of Fig. 5d correspond to anatase. or the post-irradiation for 20 min, finer needle shaped nanostrucures mixed together with some agglomerated ablated material and pherical nanoparticles are observed as in Fig. 5e. The SAED pattern f these nanostructures agree with rutile (Fig. 5f). Average size of he selected spherical particles only in this case is 15 ± 6.2 nm.
For the laser ablation using 1064 nm, spherical rutile TiO2 anoparticles were obtained at 4.7 J/cm2 and when the laser flunce was increased to 8.7 and 20.4 J/cm2, the morphology changed o needle shaped anatase TiO2 nanostructures. However, at the ighest fluence (45.9 J/cm2), larger spherical anatase TiO2 nanoparicles were dominant even though very small particles were also resent. These changes in morphologies could be due to the differnce in laser ablation energy (fluence) as it is one of the important blation parameters which is a combined effect of the laser beam aist and pulse energy that can determine the morphology and ize of nanoparticles in PLALM [12,24]. Ablation using 532 nm aser wavelength, at three laser fluence (2.8, 6 and 19.4 J/cm2), utile TiO2 spherical nanoparticles with sizes from 13–15 nm were btained, and at higher fluence, Ti8O15 anorthic smaller spherial nanoparticles (12 nm) were formed. These results showed that n our experiment as the laser fluence increased, the morphology emained similar, but size and crystalline structure of the TiO2 anomaterials changed. The effect of increase in laser fluence of he 532 nm output laser beam was reported with the formation
of the TiO2 nanoparticles formed by ablation using 532 nm at (a and b) 27.6 J/cm2
.23 J/cm2.
of titanium nanomaterials with different morphology, size and structure [25]. Also, the ablation of titanium plate at higher fluence (10 J/cm2) led to the creation of spherical nanoparticles with anatase and rutile mixed phases [13,14,18]. Formation of Ti2O3 nanoparticles occurred due to oxygen vacancies induced by the rapid and transient plasma cooling after the laser pulses [14]. TiO2 nanoparticles produced by the initial laser pulses have undergone a post-irradiation during the rest of the time of ablation. This might have contributed to the inhomogeneity of the particles.
Post-irradiation was an effort to explore its effects on morphology and structure of these nanomaterials. As a result of the post-laser irradiation of the as-prepared TiO2 nanoparticles obtained by ablation with 532 nm laser wavelength, there was a change in morphology, size and structure. In general, for 10 min post-irradiation, the average size of spherical nanoparticles increased from 12–15 nm range to 14–17 nm range for different ablation energy (fluence). For 20 min post irradiation, most of these nanocolloids maintained their average sizes in the range of 14–16 nm. Regarding the structure of these nanomaterials for 10 min post irradiation, those nanocolloids at lower fluence (2.8 and 6 J/cm2) maintained their rutile phase. For those prepared at high fluence of 19.4 and 27.6 J/cm2, anatase phase was identified by SAED analysis. For 20 min post-irradiation, all these titanium oxide nanomaterials showed rutile phase as evident from these SAED analyses. The nanocolloids obtained at 19.4 J/cm2 is rutile as per TEM results. Half of that colloid is irradiated for 10 min where the structure changes to anatase. The other half after 20 min post-irradiation, maintains as rutile. Rutile and anatase might have been present at these conditions while anatase is identified in the SAED analysis. The presence of many smaller TiO2 nanoparticles might have contained mixed phases that contributed this structural change during post irradiation as particle size has an important role in phase transformation for these nanomaterials [26–29].

sections.heading: 88 G.G. Guillén et al. / Applied Su
sections.text:
The effects of post-irradiation of these nanocolloids can be xplained using two mechanisms – laser melting and laser fragentation. The heating – melting – evaporation mechanism is esponsible for the size change [30–32], if a nanoparticle absorbs ufficient laser beam energy, it melts and/or evaporates. For the se of 532 nm to irradiate TiO2 colloids, a much higher fluence is equired for spherical particle formation. The calculated laser flunce for rutile TiO2 to heat an individual spherical particle (60 nm) o full melting is ∼0.6 J/cm2 [33]. As the laser fluence utilized in ur experiment is 0.23 J/cm2, TiO2 nanoparticles are not heated p to their melting point, but longer duration of irradiation and he presence of smaller nanoparticles increase the overall surface nergy such that the spherical nanoparticles form agglomerates aintaining their individual morphologies [34]. On macrocrystalline (bulk) regime, rutile phase is thermodyamically stable relative to that of anatase or brookite. Studies on hase transformation and kinetics of nanocrystalline anatase to utile showed that the activation energy was particle size dependnt [26]. Thermodynamic analysis of phase stability showed that hen the particle size was below 14 nm, anatase turned more stale than rutile [35]. For particle size less than or equal to 11 nm, natase was marginally stable than brookite which co-existed with natase. Another study explored the particle size dependence on he kinetic rate constant for phase transformation in nanoparticle of iO2. The nanoparticle size effects on reaction kinetics was very relvant because phase transformation occurred at lower temperature egimes [29]. A combined experimental analysis and computational odeling studies on amorphous titania nanoparticles of ∼2 nm in ize showed their thermodynamic stability. They have a highly istorted shell and a small strained anatase-like core [28]. In our esults, most of the analyses were from TEM and XPS, while those ner particles observed in TEM might be composed of two or more rystalline structures. Particle sizes evaluated for the TiO2 nanoparicles are in the range that can cause phase transformations at ower temperatures due to size effects even though particles of arger sizes are present. Our XRD results for the selected conditions howed the presence of single crystalline structure with no impuities, in good agreement with the corresponding TEM analysis on rystalline structure. Bigger or agglomerated particles could also be ffectively contributed for improved absorption of photon energy nd the phase changes during post-irradiation of the nanocolloids.
Even though the optical absorption at 532 nm for these titanium xide nanomaterials is low, presence of larger/agglomerated paricles as well as non-linear absorptions may have contributed to hese changes in structure and morphologies. However, needlehaped nanostructures were formed due to 10 min post-irradiation f the as-prepared colloids at 27.6 J/cm2. It can be explained by he surface energy growth mechanism in which during quenchng by the liquid, the surface atoms are reoriented and grow in the irection of the smaller face leading to a change in shape. After 0 min of irradiation, the needle-shaped anatase nanostructures ere almost dissolved since rutile phase is more stable than anatase 36]. Another detailed study on TiO2 nanocolloids using different avelengths of ablation and post-irradiation are in progress.
In PLALM, fabrication of nanomaterials depends on the laser arameters, nature of target material and the properties of the urrounding liquid. The size and morphologies of nanoparticles epend on laser parameters such as wavelength, pulse duration, uence, beam waist, repetition rate and number of pulses. Polarty, viscosity and refractive index of the medium play a key role n the post ablation process such as agglomeration and aggregaion. During laser ablation, a plasma plume of high temperature nd pressure will be generated on the target surface where the aser beam is focused. The laser induced plasma containing atoms,
olecules, clusters and radicals expands to the surrounding liqid that confines the plasma. This process results in a cavitation
bubble and shockwave generation. The plasma plume cools down during expansion by transfer of energy to the liquid medium and the collapse of the cavitation bubble releases nanoparticles into the surrounding liquid. The temperature gradient on both sides of the liquid-bubble interface affects the nucleation and condensation of the fabricated nanomaterials [7,15,37]. The ablation fluence is a combined effect of laser beam waist at focus and pulse energy. The lower fluence relates to a higher spot diameter on the target while the production of nanoparticles depends on the properties of the target material and the surrounding liquid also. In this process, effects of energy fluence on nanoparticle size was to increase or decrease as reported in different studies [38–41]. The size and morphology changes by laser fluence were dependent on ablation wavelength and liquid medium also [41–43].
3.2. Structure by XRD analysis
X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the titanium oxide nanomaterials obtained by laser ablation with 532 nm laser beam at 27.6 J/cm2 and their post-irradiation for 10 and 20 min are shown in Fig. 6a–c. The diffraction peak at the position of 2 equal to 29.4◦ is indexed and the calculated lattice parameter d = 3.04 Å is in agreement with the main diffraction plane (103) of anorthic Ti8O15 phase as in Fig. 6a (PDF No. 04-008-1591). After their postirradiation with 532 nm laser beam during 10 min, the diffraction pattern changed (Fig. 6b). The diffraction peaks located at the positions of 2 equal to 25.3◦, 37.8◦ and 48.0◦ in Fig. 6b correspond to the diffraction planes (101), (004) and (200) for the anatase TiO2 phase (PDF No. 04-007-0701) respectively. ig. 6c is for 20 min post-irradiation and the peaks identified at 7.5◦, 36.1◦, 41.2◦ and 54.3◦ correspond to (110), (111), (101) and 211) diffraction planes of TiO2 rutile phase (PDF No. 04-008-7645). hese XRD patterns confirm the crystalline structures of the titaium oxide nanomaterials prepared by pulsed laser ablation and ost-irradiation. These results are in good agreement with the esults of SAED analysis in TEM. Mixed phases of anatase and rutile anoparticles were obtained under 355 nm laser irradiation of TiO2 anoparticles (100 nm) dispersed in distilled water for relatively onger durations [44]. During 30 min or longer irradiation time, a ransformation from anatase to rutile phase was obtained because f the better stability for rutile phase under higher temperature and ressure caused by pulsed laser irradiation.
.3. Chemical states by XPS analysis
The elemental composition and oxidation states analysis of itanium dioxide nanoparticles produced in distilled water by ablaion with 1064 and 532 nm laser wavelengths were done using PS. Binding energies of all the peaks were corrected using C1s nergy at 284.6 eV corresponding to adventitious carbon in addiion to the charge compensation by the flood gun associated with he spectrometer. The peaks were de-convoluted using a Shirley ype background calculation and peak fitting was done using a aussian–Lorentzian sum function. The high resolution spectra of i 2p and O1s recorded are given in Fig. 7A and B. All spectra were ollected after a surface etching by 2 keV Ar+ ions for 20 s in order o clean the surface and reduce the amount of carbon and oxygen ontaminants due to the environmental exposure of the samples. ig. 7A-I shows the Ti 2p3/2 and Ti 2p1/2 core levels peaks of the anocolloids obtained by laser ablation with 1064 nm at 45.9 J/cm2. he peaks observed at 459.1 eV and 464.7 eV correspond to the xidation state of Ti4+ in TiO2 [45]. The high resolution core level pectrum O1s inset in (I) shows different peaks, the peak located t 530.8 eV correspond to O2− in TiO2. When the laser ablation was one with 1064 nm laser at 20.4 J/cm2 (Fig. 7A-II), the core level pectrum for Ti 2p shows a broader peak that contains two peaks t slightly different energies indicating the presence of other elecronic states. Ti 2p3/2 and Ti 2p1/2 are located at the binding energies f 458.3 eV and 463.9 eV, 459.2 eV and 464.8 eV, which correspond o the range of binding energies values reported in the literature o Ti4+ in TiO2 [45]. Inset in Fig. 7A-II, the O1s core level spectrum f this sample shows peaks at binding energies of 529.7 eV and 30.7 eV due to Ti–O–Ti [45].
Fig. 7B shows the high resolution core level spectral analysis f Ti2p and O1s for titanium oxide nanomaterials produced by aser ablation at fluence of 27.6 and 19.4 J/cm2 (III and IV), their 0 min post-irradiation (V and VI) and 20 min post-irradiation (VII nd VIII) respectively. The Ti2p and O1s high resolution spectra in II, V and VII for the colloids obtained by the ablation with 532 nm aser at 27.6 J/cm2 and post irradiated for 10 and 20 min agree well n their peak positions, width and binding energy values of Ti and
in TiO2. The peaks located at 459.2 (III), 458.4 (V) and 458.9 eV V) correspond to the oxidation state of Ti4+ and the correspondng O1s peaks located at the binding energies of 530.9, 530.1 and 30.3 eV which are the characteristic O2-, and all correspond to iO2. The Ti2p core level spectra of the colloids produced by the blation with 532 nm at 19.4 J/cm2 and their post-irradiation with 32 nm laser during 10 and 20 min are in Fig. 7B (IV, VI and VIII). he doublet peaks, Ti 2p3/2 and Ti 2p1/2, in Fig. 7B-IV, located at 59.7 eV and 565.2 eV are the energies corresponding to the elecronic state Ti4+ as reported in literature. The high resolution Ti
p core level spectrum in Fig. 7b-VI is deconvoluted in two doulet peaks, these are located at binding energies of 457.6 eV and 63.1 eV, 458.7 eV and 464.3 eV, and they correspond to the oxiation state Ti3+ (Ti2O3) and Ti4+ (TiO2), respectively [45]. Inset in
Science 405 (2017) 183–194 189
those figures are the corresponding O1s peaks located at binding energies of 530.2 eV, 529.4 eV and 530.3 eV. In Fig. 7B (VIII), the Ti 2p peak positons identified at 459.5 and 465.1 eV corresponds to Ti4+ in TiO2, the oxygen peak at 530.3 is also identified. Other deconvoluted peaks identified in O1s spectra in all the cases could be due to the presence of other oxides of titanium nanomaterials such as TiO, Ti2O3 and Ti8O15. The presence of these phases cannot be neglected because of the extremely high energy plasma and synthesis by reactive laser ablation of titanium in distilled water.
TiO2 nanomaterials synthesized by pulsed laser ablation of TiO2 rutile target in distilled water showed binding energies values of Ti 2p at 459.1 eV and 458.9 eV. A peak located at 532.1 eV in O1s core level implied that the surface of the as-synthesized filamentous species were partially covered with hydroxide OH groups [46]. These values were similar to those of tetravalent Ti ion in TiO2 [47]. Also, individual Ti 2p3/2 peak located at 456.4, 457.6 and 458.5 eV, were attributed to Ti2+ (TiO), Ti3+(Ti2O3) and Ti4+ (TiO2) [18]. Also, TiO2 rutile nanoparticles with spherical morphologies were synthesized by PLALM showed two Ti 2p3/2 peaks at the binding energies of 458.8 eV and 460.5 eV. The first one was attributed to Ti4+ in TiO2; the second one was associated with Ti2p3/2 in the TiOx/Ti compound. The TiOx/Ti is in agreement with the extreme nonequilibrium condition in the laser ablation process [48]. In another research work, the binding energy of 458.2 and 462.5 eV were attributed to the Ti 2p3/2 and Ti 2p1/2 core level of Ti3+, respectively [49,50]. The peak energies at 458.7 and 463.7 eV were related to the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 core level of Ti4+, respectively [51]. Our results are in good agreement with the reported values of the binding energies and chemical states of Ti and O in titanium oxide. XPS analysis of the ablated products confirmed the elemental and chemical states of the titanium oxide nanomaterials.
3.4. Optical properties by UV–vis spectroscopy analysis
Fig. 8 shows the optical absorption spectra and band gap evaluated for the nanocolloids prepared by pulsed laser ablation with 532 nm and 1064 nm laser at different laser fluence. Also, the colloids resulted from the post-irradiation using 532 nm laser are included in Fig. 8c and d. The different optical behavior of all the samples is identified by a change in the slope of their optical absorbance spectra in the UV-blue region. From the figure, absorbance increases with decrease in ablation fluence for both cases of 532 and 1064 nm. It shows that the nanocolloids synthesized at lower ablation fluence are more concentrated than those obtained at higher fluence. The optical band gap values estimated for all the nanoparticle colloidal solutions are illustrated as insets of Fig. 8a–d. These values were evaluated by graphically extrapolating the Tauc plot for direct band gap materials (( h )2 vs h ). The wavelength range used to calculate the energy (h ) was the same as in the absorption spectra and the Beer–Lambert equation was used to calculate the coefficient of absorption. For ablation using 532 nm laser output, the estimated optical band gap values increased from 3.3 eV to 3.7 eV when the ablation energy increased from 2.8 J/cm2 to 27.6 J/cm2 (Fig. 8a). As the ablation wavelength changed to 1064 nm the optical band gap of the TiO2 nanoparticles synthesized at different fluence varied from 2.8 eV to 3.3 eV as the laser fluence changed from 4.7 J/cm2 to 45.9 J/cm2 as shown in Fig. 8b. A blue shift in the optical band gaps was observed for the TiO2 nanoparticles synthesized by ablation using 532 nm compared to those obtained at 1064 nm as well as those reported (3 eV for rutile and 3.2 eV for anatase) [52]. Fig. 8c and d describe the optical band gaps evaluated when the post-irradiation was done for the colloids prepared by 532 nm ablation. The optical band gap after 10 and 20 min of post-irradiation were in the range of 3.0–3.7 eV. A fluence dependence of the optical band gap was observed such that it increased to higher energies as the laser fluence is increased

sections.text:
n ablation using both wavelengths. The blue shift in energy can be ue to the presence of smaller TiO2 spherical nanoparticles which is vident from the TEM images of nanoparticles under various condiions of laser ablation and post-irradiation. TiO2 anatase spherical anoparticles were synthesized by PLALM, with a band gap energy f 3.34 eV [17], that represented a blue shift of 0.14 eV relative o bulk anatase (3.2 eV) [52]. However, by ablation with 1064 nm aser wavelength, not much changes were observed in the band ap energy, which could be due to the formation of agglomerated pherical nanoparticles as well as the presence of different phases f titanium oxide nanomaterials. Energy band gap values in this ange have been already reported for TiO2 spherical nanoparticles ynthesized by PLALM, which present two distinct values of band ap energies, 2.9 eV and 3.1 eV [13,14,19], suggesting that reduction f the energy gap is due to the generation of defect states within he gap from the oxygen vacancies [21,53]. A red shift and peakroadening of the band-edge absorption can result from the size ncrease of the nanoparticles, presence of different morphologies r due to the presence of mixed phases [33].
.5. Emission spectra by PL analysis
Photoluminescence (PL) analysis is a highly sensitive and ependable technique for investigating electronic properties of aterials. Luminescence measurements were carried out at room
ig. 7. Ti 2p and O1s core level spectra of the nanoparticles obtained by ablation using (A 9.4 J/cm2, (V) post irradiated for 10 min (27.6 J/cm2), (VI) post irradiated for 10 min (19 anocolloid) and (VIII) post irradiated for 20 min using 532 nm, 0.23 J/cm2 (19.4 J/cm2 TiO
Science 405 (2017) 183–194
temperature using an excitation wavelength of 260 nm and the scanning wavelength range was 300–480 nm (4.1–2.6 eV). Fig. 9 represents the emission spectra for the as-synthesized colloidal TiO2 nanoparticles using 532 nm (Fig. 9a) and 1064 nm (Fig. 9b) laser beam. Also, the emission spectra of the colloids obtained by the post-irradiation of the 532 nm colloids during 10 and 20 min are included in Fig. 9c and d, respectively. We can observe that all these nanocolloids are emissive with peaks in the blue wavelength region of the visible spectra. The emission spectra for the TiO2 nanoparticles comprise two emission peaks, a dominant one located at higher photon energy and another one at lower energy. Only 10 min post-irradiated TiO2 colloid obtained at 19.4 J/cm2 shows an extra emission peak. For the colloidal nanoparticles prepared by ablation using 532 nm at different fluence (Fig. 9a), the blue emission peak with a maximum at 382 nm (3.2 eV) is prominent, while the other emission peak located in the range of 397 nm–436 nm (3.1 eV and 2.8 eV) is less intense. For the ablation using 1064 nm (Fig. 9b), there is an intense peak located at 408 nm (3.0 eV). The intense UV-blue emission peak of TiO2 nanoparticles obtained by postirradiation of the 532 nm colloids, during 10 min (Fig. 9c) is located at 383 nm (3.2 eV). Another UV-emission peak at 354 nm (3.5 eV) for the 10 min post irradiation is detected. For post-irradiation of 20 min (Fig. 9d), the more intense emission peak remains at 383 (3.3 eV) nm and the less intense emission peak is located at 410 nm (3.0 eV). These emission peaks are similar as the case of

These two emission peaks were originated from the defects, oxygen vacancies, based on the extreme non-equilibrium growth process of rutile nanoparticles [48,56].

In general, the PL emission in visible range for TiO2 is attributed o oxygen vacancies present. In our results, these PL emissions ere blue shifted due to the presence of smaller TiO2 nanoaterials produced by laser ablation. In PL analysis, the highest

emission intensities were corresponding to the lowest fluence and the emission peak intensities decreased as the laser fluence increased for both 532 and 1064 nm. The results were the same for the laser post-irradiated nanocolloids of 10 and 20 min also.

he optical absorption results showed that the higher concentraions of nanocolloids were for those formed at lower fluence. The ame reason could be the cause of higher emission intensity for ower fluence. Further complete analysis of PL spectra of these TiO2 anocolloids at a higher spectral resolution using different excitaion wavelengths and power densities are needed to obtain details f the energy levels involved in these emissions and the mechaisms or factors that cause blue shift as well as extra emissions.
A summary of all the experimental conditions utilized in this xperiment to synthesize titanium oxide nanomaterials such as aser ablation wavelength, fluence and details of post-irradiation re shown in Table 1. Also important results obtained such as the verage size of the spherical nanoparticles, optical bandgaps and uminescence emission wavelengths are described. Effects of ablaion conditions and post-irradiation on the average particle size, ptical bandgap and luminescence are evident from this table.
. Conclusions
Pulsed laser ablation of a Ti metal rod in distilled water using ifferent ablation wavelengths and energy resulted in titanium ioxide nanomaterials with different morphology, size, structural nd optical properties. For ablation with 532 nm laser wavelength, s the laser fluence increased, size of these nanoparticles decreased. s 1064 nm laser fluence increased, there was a change from
lation using (a) 532 nm and (b) for 1064 nm at different laser fluence; (c) 10 min of
spherical to needle-shaped TiO2 nanostructures. By laser postirradiation of TiO2 nanocolloids, the morphology and size were modified. Changes in crystalline structure of TiO2 nanomaterials by post-irradiation was confirmed by the results of SAED, XRD and their elemental and chemical states by XPS analysis. UV–vis absorption results showed a blue shift in the optical band gap energies with increase in laser fluence. The luminescence emission for these TiO2 nanocolloids was in the range of 3.0–3.5 eV. These results showed that ablation wavelength and energy as well as laser post-irradiation were effective in modifying the size, morphology, structure and optical properties of titanium dioxide nanomaterials obtained by PLALM. Structural and morphological changes due to post-irradiation of TiO2 nanocolloids prepared PLALM are reported for the first time. This study explores laser post-irradiation as an effective technique for modification of physical properties of nanomaterials.
Acknowledgments
The authors are thankful to CONACYT – México (Project 214282) and CEMIE-Sol Project 35 (CONACYT-SENER) for the financial assistance. Grisel García G is grateful to CONACYT-México for providing a doctoral research fellowship.

referenceMentions.context: Various chemical preparation methods to synhesize nanostructured titanium dioxide were reported, such as ol–gel [5,6], hydrothermal [7], micro-emulsion [8] and solvotheral method [9].

metadata.abstractText: Nanomaterials of titanium oxide were prepared by pulsed laser ablation of a titanium metal target in distilled water. The ablation was performed at different laser energy (fluence) using a nanosecond pulsed Nd:YAG laser output of 1064 and 532 nm. A post-irradiation of titanium oxide nanocolloids obtained by ablation using 532 nm was carried out to explore its effects on the structure and properties. Analysis of morphology, crystalline phase, elemental composition, chemical state, optical and luminescent properties were performed using Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM), X-Ray Diffraction (XRD), X-Ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS), UV–-vis absorption spectroscopy and room temperature pho-
metadata.creator: Elsevier
